neutron_tempest_plugin/scenario/test_qos.message: how this test is really different than what is in L255-286? IMO the use case which You described is already covered there. Do You think we should have 2 separate tests for that? If so, maybe we should simplify a bit existing test above?

This test is about "port priority" check, see:
https://docs.openstack.org/mitaka/networking-guide/config-qos.html search for: 
"The meaning of this is that any compute port connected to the network will use the network policy by default unless the port has a specific policy attached to it. Network owned ports like DHCP and router ports are excluded from network policy application."
The "test_qos_basic_and_update" is already covers several scenarios: basic and update for both options: network and port, but "port priority" is not covered in it.

I think that having "port priority" test a separate test would be better than adding into the existing, because it's already "too long" and in case of failure it will require some time to find out what exactly went wrong: basic network? basic port? update network, update port, port priority?

Please ignore my previous comment, you are right "port priority" is covered in "test_qos_basic_and_update".
I'll modify the existing test code a bit in my next patch.
So in case of failure it will be clear what exactly went wrong: basic, update, port priority.

neutron/agent/ovn/metadata/agent.py.message: We are connected to br-int, shall we populate a class attribute only when the OVS datapath is 'netdev'? I understand there's not much of a hit if doing it unconditionally but as there is no need, I wonder if we should do it only for DPDK, which is when this is only needed.
That's what I comment in the commit message: the overhead is minimal and works for every datapath type. We don't need to make this conditional (although I documented it in the method description).

I understand what you say but it's probably also that the majority of the setups are non DPDK so a bug or an issue with this checksum fill would affect unnecessarily most of the environments.

Especially when the cost is so low I'd do it conditionally 😊 I'd send a follow up patch myself otherwise. Here it's how I think that the code would look like:



ovs_dp = self.ovs_idl.db_get('Bridge', self.ovn_bridge, 'datapath_type')
if ovs_dp == 'netdev':


$ sudo ovs-vsctl get bridge br-int datapath_type                                                                                                                                           
system

How much is "minimal", 1% ? 2% ?

Do we have any data points that measured this ?

If we do not, perhaps it would be good to take the safer path and only set this if it's DPDK. I don't know much about DPDK but based on daniel's comment it doesn't seem that difficult ?

Another point is the iptables vs nftables that was discussed in the PTG, I see we are using iptables for this so I assume we do have a similar command for nftables when time comes ?

This is going to handle the metadata traffic. That happens only during the VM boot. I'm not talking about 1% of traffic, but 0.000001%.

We still don't have the NFTables manager implemented so for now we'll use iptables.

In any case, I'll make this method conditional to the datapath.

Thanks Rodolfo for the answer. I understand but probably the majority of the use cases fall in the non DPDK datapath (ie. most of the times we won't need this) and the cost of checking the datapath type is minimal. IMHO, it'd be best to fill the checksum only for DPDK especially since it's very easy (just check the bridge datapath and we're connecting already to its UNIX socket) and doesn't require any type of maintenance of migration path.

As I said, I understand there's not much of a hit if doing it unconditionally but since the right way to do is doing it only when needed and the cost of it doesn't seem too high, I'd lean more towards this approach.

container_config_scripts/pacemaker_resou.message: I wonder how much this shows better than building diff xmls off the shadow CIB copies and calling --patch against the live cib. With concurrent operations that showed off to be more resilient in the past. But I know not much about that --modify. I hope it works as well for that case!

the --modify provides the same semantics (replacing a specific pattern in the CIB with something else), as well as the same concurrency guarantee. I can do so because I'm only changing a single parameter in the CIB, so I don't need to compile a crm_diff for that.

Going the shadow CIB route would just mean extra steps: 1) snapshot the CIB 2) update the snapshot CIB and extract a crm_diff out of it 3) pushing the diff in the live CIB 4) cleaning up the snapshot CIB.

multus-config/centos/multus-config.spec.message:
We can’t package a log file like this - as soon you patch this package, you’d lose the logs.

That said, it looks like there are a couple of instances where there are logfiles owned by packages, namely the dnf logs and /var/log/keystone/keystone.log.

The dnf-data RPM has %ghost entries for the log files - which doesn’t really do much, I think. I believe it’s pretty much just to ensure the logfile is deleted if the package is removed, which wouldn’t happen for our system. It doesn’t create the file on install, so I think the permissions metadata doesn’t do much (unless you’re auditing or asking RPM to fix permissions).

The keystone one is slightly more complex. Looking at the spec:
$MY_WORKSPACE/std/srpm_assemble/openstack-keystone/rpmbuild/SPECS/openstack-keystone.spec

It has a %postinstall scriptlet that does a “touch /var/log/keystone/keystone.log” and sets the ownership and permissions, and has the logfile added with %ghost for package ownership.

I’m not a fan of this method, but if there’s no other way to get the permissions set properly…

The response still does not address my concern that the permissions will not be set correctly for a newly installed system that attempts to change the permissions of the file before it is created.  If influxd is not able to write logs to the file if the file is created beforehand, that likely means it was created as root and therefore was not writable.  Can you confirm the file ownership when created as part of the ExecStartPre?  If it is not correct, is something like the following required?

ExecStartPre=-/usr/bin/touch /var/log/influxdb/influxd.log
ExecStartPre=-/usr/bin/chown influxdb:influxdb /var/log/influxdb/influxd.log
ExecStartPre=-/usr/bin/chmod 640 /var/log/influxdb/influxd.log

I have tested the case where permission change is done after ExecStart using ExecStartPost. The behavior is the same as the above implementation, meaning the permission changes to 640 only after the service is restarted. Logs are written in influxd.log during installation and continue after the restart.
I have also tested the case where the log file is created as part of ExecStartPre and the permission gets changed also using ExecStartPre. The behavior is that the log file is created with permission 640 at installation time but is empty, so the process influxdb is not able to write logs.
Resolved by setting the proper ownership.

metalsmith_ansible/ansible_plugins/modul.message: nit: could we also support non-cloud-init user data?

Right now the internal implementation is tied to cloud-init cloud-config to create the admin user, but we could change that so that if user_name is None and cloud_config is None then no cloud-config is built and the user-data can be consumed by whatever other tool.

We could in the future add a user_data suboption. There will sometimes need to be cloud-config under the hood, so if they specify user_data as well then we build a multi-part archive message which contains both, see https://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/format.html#mime-multi-part-archive

metalsmith_ansible/ansible_plugins/modul.message: Agree this would be more clear.

The problem I have with calling cloud-config a script is that it implies imperative instructions called in order. Whereas cloud-config[1] is a declarative dict of tasks run in the order cloud-init determines (some of the tasks can be scripts though)

I'm open to improving this wording in a way which satisfies my own pedantry :) For now I'll change it to:

  Dict of cloud-init cloud-config tasks to run on node boot.

[1] https://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/examples.html
It's not a cloud-init metadata, it's pretty standard.

This is not bash syntax, or at least you're using it in a misleading way. You're not setting ACTIVE_CONTROLLER_NOT_FOUND to the boolean true, you're just setting it to a string. This is also prone to easily being broken by someone in the future, like if the spot where you are setting this variable ends up in a subprocess for whatever reason, or if someone decides this is incomplete because it's not globally set with a default "false" value.

Please be consistent with the script and do your checks as:
if [ -e "${ACTIVE_CONTROLLER_NOT_FOUND_FLAG}" ]

> Is this the correct syntax

Yes, [ ${ACTIVE_CONTROLLER_NOT_FOUND} ] will be true if it is set (or defined) to a value. Otherwise it will be false.

This can be tested by:
  [ ${foobar} ] && echo "foobar is set" || echo "foobar is unset"

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message:
Baseurls sounds like a good solution, though it also sounds like there's more than one url, but urlparse splits it into components.  But still, I don't have any problem with variables being redefined.  I don't think it's unclear at all.  We know that "=" in python is an assignment operator.  After line 1400, baseurl is the result of urlunparse; it doesn't matter what it was before that line.   So if it was ever okay to write "baseurl = urlunparse(baseurls)" then it should be okay to write "baseurl = urlunparse(baseurl)".

Some people don't agree with that, which is why in the MS world Hungarian notation is traditionally popular.  This would be "strBaseURL = urlunparse(arrBaseURL)".  That's very similar to what is suggested here.  I am part of the group that actively reacted against that and moved to Python.

To be clear, I'd never argue about this stylistic choice normally.  I would not -1 any of the ways anyone here has suggested writing this code.  I only bring it up now since we're evaluating how useful mypy is.

Is this really necessary?  The code seems fine as written.  Is there anyway to have mypy let us change types at runtime?  I think this paradigm is very useful and quite readable (promoting variables through types and discarding unused versions).  In other situations, one might go through 3 or 4 type transitions to get to the final version, and there's no need to keep all of those.

> In other situations, one might go through 3 or 4 type transitions to get to the final version, and there's no need to keep all of those.

I'd argue this is a micro optimization and the focus should be more to make the code easy to read. Going from `baseurls` to a single `baseurl` makes it clear that the variable was a list of baseurls and has transitioned to a single one.

Though that causes more problems when the function is larger than this.
There is `--allow-redefinition` which seems like useful for zuul code-base.

when i was at intel i also had to deal with issues related to the use of devname. on older kernels e.g. ubuntu 14.04 or before the bios dev names stuff landed it was common for the
vf or pf name top change after they were used by a vm

e.g. eth3->eth10

even with the predicable nic names in later kernels
depending on your udev rules the kernel/udev may not bind the PF or VF back to a nic driver and may instead elect to leave them bound to vfio-pci. if that happens the device wont have a netdev for the pf or vf and if your restart the nova compute agent it wont discover the device by its name and it will remove it from the pci resouce tracker.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1589796 which is what is prompting stephen to submit is an instance of that last case were the nova compute agent container is restarted and it nolonger fineds the pfs/vfs.


this has been a pain in the ass since it was intoduced and i flat out ban using it in intel openstack reference architecture because it just could not be relied on which is why they always used the pci addres and or the vendor id/product id in the examples.

the other reason to remove it is it only works with nic.

you can have resonable device names for other types of pci device like pci ssd genrall have a device name but devname only works with nics where as all the other ways work for any device.

its not intel specific i have seen this happen with connectx-3 nics in the past.

without that change if you restart the compute agent while
the vm is activlying using a vf that was whiltlist using devname, then the vf will be removed form the database.

if the vm i later stopped, the vf would be rebound to the host and rediscovered by the pci track and added as free.

then a second instance can be schduled to the same vf in a similar way to what is described in the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1633120

meaning if you start the first vm again it will cause one or both of the vms to crash as both attempt to use the same VF.

this is now fixed which is why i did not bring it up initially but for years it was totally broken to restart the compute service whiele any vm was using a pci device that was whitelisted via devname.

generall just works so this has no implciation for standard ovs. the issue is with PCI hotplug which is effectily what happens when you do a sriov PF or VF passthouhg.

so dont take away the view we can rely on netdev names for neutorn in general but sriov can expose edgecase that dont otherwise happen.

there are two factors at play here.
1. will a pf/vf be bound to a nic driver or left with vfio-pci 
2 if the device is bound back to a nic driver will it get a consitent name.

the question of will it the nic be bound to a nic driver instad of vfio-pci depend on a number of factors

1 which of the following are you using to manage your devices udev, systemd-udevd, mdev/buysbox-mdev
2 have you defined any custom udev rules
3 your device vendor/kernel driver version
4 has /sys/class/net/*/device/driver_override been modifed since system boot.
5 have you blacklisted any dirvers using modeprobe setting.

generally if you do 4 or 5 then you wont be using devnames
as its more or less mutally exclsive.


assuming your device manger will attempt to bind the pf/vf back to a nic driver then that brings use to the second point. consistent names.

The changes that enable consitent device nameing are partly kernel dependant but also depend on a few other factors.
firstly there are several supported nameing schemes
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/networking_guide/ch-consistent_network_device_naming

form a rhel/centos perspective the kernel nameing scheme (Scheme 5) changes between rhel 7.2 and 7.3 due to backport for the upstream  4.x series. 

the primary factors that effect how your device will be named are as follows:

1 do you have a new enought smbios and firmware to support biosdevnames
2 is biosdevnames installed
3 is your systemd new enough to use it own consistent nameing scheme
4 is the bug related to having both biosdevnames and systemd-udev fixed
5 are you on rhel 7.3+ and still have net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0 see https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1425787

point number 5 is what used to be the most common cause
of issue with devname. reverting to the ETH* names is/was supported when people first deployed on centos 7 and while we not recommend against doign this many customer that ignored that recommentation expericen issue with devname.

This statement is not correct, what about physical_network ? thats also a NIC feature.

my take here is that passthrough whitelist has evolved to contain NIC attributes.

pyhical network is a tag not a filed use for filtering.
they are two different things
I see, thanks for clarifying.
This will not work in case of multiple NICs of the same vendor:product connected to different physnets
what about SR-IOV on dual port NICs connected to different physnets ?

So the approach is to tailor using PCI regex, can't imagine it would be fun during deployment.

also im not sure VF PCI enumeration behaves the same on all hardware. 

Anyway, during deployment, one could inspect sys/bus/pci/devices/<PF-D:B:D.f>/virtfn*
and create the appropriate whitelist.

One caveat that i can think of is scaling up/down sriov VFs will require whitelist update in some cases.
for that usecase you need to use the pci address.
What is the recommendation for SR-IOV deployments e.g with TripleO? define SR-IOV role per server type ?

possibly, i avoid trippleo where i can.

we intend to drop support for this parmater downstream in OSP in the next LTS release of OSP. triplo may continue to supprot it but we are updaing our documentiaon to recmonned that it is not used. we may need to work with our deployment folks to ensure there is an easy replacement but even today we recommend using the pci address rexex capablity with the vendor id and product id not the devname.

os_vif/internal/ip/ip_command.py.message: these should be on the seam line

> if we want to do it consistently always use hanging indent if it
 > does not fit on a single lin and pack with the retrun value and
 > close ) on the same line as the last parameter.

The problem putting a return on the same line is that it means I need to indent all of the parameters to distinguish them from the body of the function. For example:

  def hello_world(
      param_a, param_b) -> int:
      if param_a:
          do_something(param_b)
  
      ...

isn't readable and has to be rewritten as:

  def hello_world(
          param_a, param_b) -> int:
      if param_a:
          do_something(param_b)
  
      ...

which wastes 5% of my available width, which is a lot when 5-15 is already gone with basic indentation. It also makes longer return types more challenging since I'm now losing whatever width is used by the parameters on that line, not to mention being ugly af :)

This is easy, looks decent and we don't have to think about things. More importantly, gets basic type hints into the bulk of the code base.

I've nothing against moving to automated code formatting, but it's a very big hammer when simply holding your nose a little would accomplish the same thing. Remember, doing this work took me not insignificant time so I think it's only fair that I be a little opinionated in how it looks.

I'd really want to keep them on separate lines. I know it is occasionally wasteful space-wise, but it's the correct thing to do 80-90% of the time. Rather than trying to decide, let's just do this consistently. The only exception is where *all* arguments fit on one line. I'm sure there are examples of that in here somewhere

and i would really want to never have argument on a new line unless they dont fit.

if we want to do it consistently always use hanging indent if it does not fit on a single lin and pack with the retrun value and close ) on the same line as the last parameter.

the only way im ok with requiring the formatting you are proposing is if we move to automated code formatting. if we want to do that ill work on a set of formating rules with you that we can both live with and we will start using that.

no we should not add this to the pep8 env
we still have a todo to remove it form the pep8 job in nova and move it to the linters job.

can you add a linters env instead and then enable the linters job in the zuul.yaml instead.

While I'd normally agree with you, I'm afraid the battle for 'linters' rather than 'pep8' has been lost. The 'openstack-python3-victoria-jobs' template that everyone should be using includes the 'openstack-tox-pep8' job, which means we're always going to be running a 'pep8' job. If I add 'linters', we're going to be running 'flake8' twice, which is pretty wasteful. Alternatively, if I only add 'mypy' to 'linters' then 'linters' won't be running all linters. We just have to live with the bad naming, IMO

im suggesting not including flake8 in linters
and using linter for the other linters.

test/probe/test_replication_servers_work.message: Would be good to have a little more explanation here

this shouldn't be necessary. If it is necessary then it implies that maybe the rehash/consolidation was necessary at end of last cycle after all. But, I removed the change and probe test passes for me.

I added this after seeing https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/3714d89c0c7b498fae3df1959c15b6d3/log/job-output.txt#1124-1129

There definitely is a chance that we see the files get replicated (and break out of the loop) while the suffixes are still sitting in the .invalid. If we go unlinking a bunch of data *before* we've actually rehashed, of course the rehash will say "I don't have this" and when we run the replicators down at L174, we'll go copying data.

Since the point of the loop is to get things to a settled state, it seemed (to me) like running replicators one more time would be acceptable.

FWIW, if I run this test 10x without this change, I tend to get ~2 failures with a pretty even split on TestReplicatorFunctions vs TestReplicatorFunctionsReservedNames.

OK I see it now: the next part of the test verifies/demonstrates that once the hashes.pkl is up to date then deleting object files under hood would not be detected by subsequent replication. If the replicator on test_node ran *after the objects had been replicated* during the last cycle then it would have already caused rehash to update hashes.pkl, so the test would proceed OK as it was. But if the test_node replicator ran before the object data was replicated, then test_node is left with invalid hashes in hashes.invalid which means that the next part of the test *would* replicate data and fail.
